title: Why have I lost interest in writing suddenly after years of passionate pursuing? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although I am not much qualified for this, but still, let me share my experience. When I started writing, I was appreciated by a couple of people around me. I wrote stuff, and mind you I even got appreciation from once who’d been really rude to me at times. This was when I thought, “Dude, you are a writer. That’s your passion.” But you know, soon all the appreciation dried up. I went through a really low phase. I made a blog which had 1 follower, and yeah that was me. Forget criticism, I felt ignored. It was then that I realized, “If you’re even gonna do anything worthwhile, you’re bound to face difficulties, you’re bound to face adversities. EVEN IF YOU’RE FOLLOWING YOU’RE PASSION, YOU’LL FACE PROBLEMS. And on the face of adversities, you really need a reason to continue, you need discipline to slog further.” We think that once we find our passion, our life would become very easy. But guess what, No it won’t. We’ll still have to face problems, sometimes even bigger. I told myself, “Dude, you say you’re a writer. Well then, write something so inspirational that pumps you up and makes you create crazy content.” And I discovered that I can write motivational stuff too. I can relate to you, but man, you already have a full-fledged novel with you! See, you’ve something to look at and be proud of yourself. You’re bound to go through low phases, but that’s where you’re actually tested. That’s where you realize if you can really continue the fight. You enjoyed writing right? Just keep writing. Soon you’ll start enjoying it again. Write on a paper. Write messy things. Write totally unrelated stuff. Try something out of your niche for a while. Write your feeling. Write snippets, or maybe write something to motivate yourself. Just write for a bit longer time. You’ve asked this question. It makes me conclude that you still want to write. So give writing a chance. Force yourself to write at least 500–1000 words everyday. And if you really wanna write, you’ll start enjoying it again. The only advice I can give you is that though motivation is important, but consistency and discipline are more important. Become consistent. Become Disciplined, and just write. . Yours truly, Unnamed. Footnotes : WHY EXACTLY DO YOU NEED A “WHY”
